microstructure: dual-phases microstructure with two disordered BCC phases
evidence: W and Mo are added to the HfNbTaTiZr high entropy alloy to improve its high-temperature performance. Microstructures, and mechanical properties of new refractory high-entropy alloys, HfNbTaTiZrW (H-W) and HfNbTaTiZrMoW (H-MoW), were studied. W and/or Mo additions broaden the two-phases temperature range and introduced two disordered BCC phases in contrast with the single BCC phase in HfNbTaTiZr. Attributing to the dual-phases microstructure and the strong solid solution strengthening effect, H-W and H-MoW exhibit substantially improved yield strengths at 25e1200 C compared with HfNbTaTiZr. Particularly, at 1200 C, H-W and H-MoW show yield strengths of 345 MPa and 703 MPa, which are much higher than 92 MPa of HfNbTaTiZr.

microstructure: dual-phases microstructure with two disordered BCC phases
evidence: W and Mo are added to the HfNbTaTiZr high entropy alloy to improve its high-temperature performance. Microstructures, and mechanical properties of new refractory high-entropy alloys, HfNbTaTiZrW (H-W) and HfNbTaTiZrMoW (H-MoW), were studied. W and/or Mo additions broaden the two-phases temperature range and introduced two disordered BCC phases in contrast with the single BCC phase in HfNbTaTiZr. Attributing to the dual-phases microstructure and the strong solid solution strengthening effect, H-W and H-MoW exhibit substantially improved yield strengths at 25e1200 C compared with HfNbTaTiZr. Particularly, at 1200 C, H-W and H-MoW show yield strengths of 345 MPa and 703 MPa, which are much higher than 92 MPa of HfNbTaTiZr.
As shown in Fig.  6  (a), the H-W alloy exhibits the yield strength of 1550 MPa at RT, and reaches the peak strength (2322 MPa) at ε ¼ 26.3% and fails at ε ¼ 26.3%.
H-MoW exhibits yield strength ~700 MPa and fracture strain >35% at 1200 C.
H-MoW exhibits yield strength ~700 MPa and fracture strain >35% at 1200 C.

microstructure: Two disordered BCC phases: dendrite (rich in W, Ta, Nb) and interdendrite (rich in Hf, Zr, Ti)
evidence: Both H-W and H-MoW exhibit two disordered BCC phases in each alloy, and they correspond to dendrite regions and interdendrite regions respectively. The dendrite BCC phase is rich in high melting point elements (W, Ta, and Nb) whereas the interdendrite BCC phase is rich in low melting point elements (Hf, Zr, and Ti).
